p: The literature on climate change and health is evolving rapidly. For example, Hess et al. [ 16] reviewed the work of authors including Ebi and Burton [ 17], Ebi et al. [ 18], Ebi and Semenza [ 19], Ebi et al. [ 20], concluding that while there is substantial literature on identifying climate change impacts on public health, little focusses on public health interventions. To reconcile evidence-based public health (EBPH) with CCA and health, Hess et al. [ 16] modified Jones et al ’s [ 21] EBPH framework to incorporate CCA concerns. Likewise, the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention developed the standalone ‘Building Resilience Against Climate Effects’ (BRACE) framework, which Marinucci et al. [ 22] described as suitable for assessing climate-related impacts on health as well as for prioritising interventions. While these authors focussed on the climate-health interface, the research presented here focusses on how effectively ROs are supporting health related CCA.
